bug.short_desc: [compiler] Null analysis for fields does not take @com.google.inject.Inject into account

long_desc.thetext: We're using Google Guice (com.google.inject) dependency injection, which means that a field annotated with @Inject cannot be null unless it is explicitly annotated as @Inject(optional=true). Since Kepler M5, JDT's null pointer analysis for fields reports errors on almost all fields now.

This is in line with some of what we discussed in bug 383371. It's not trivial to precisely capture the semantic of the various libraries and frameworks out there (incl. persistence frameworks which have the same issue).
It's good we now have a ticket for this.

Are static fields with @Inject relevant? Can an injector guarantee non-nullness for those?
I couldn't find any non-null guarantees regarding javax.inject.Inject. Is that specified anywhere?
It is possible to inject values into static fields with Guice, though it has to be requested explicitly. For the sake of simplicity, I'd treat javax.inject.Inject and com.google.Inject equally.

Released for 4.3 M6 via commit 03f2d9cad83654a82360483795a7407e799378bf.
For the records: - both @Inject types are treated equally (despite that lack of specification for javax.inject.Inject). - optional=true is respected - the patch concerns only member fields
Verified for 4.3 M6 with build I20130310-2000.
